Introduction to Proofs

Example: Theorem--If $n$ is an ondd integer then $n^2 + 1$ is even
Proof--The statement is of the form $\forall n (P(n) \implies Q(n))$

Assume $P(n)$
$n$ is odd
$\therefore \exists k: n = 2k + 1$
$n^2 + 1 = (2k + 1)^2 + 1 = 4k^2 + 4k + 1 = 2(k^2 + 2k + 1)$
$n^2 + 1 = 2m$ for some integer $m$, namely $k^2 + 2k + 1$.
$\therefore n^2 + 1$ is even
$\therefore Q(n)$

A theorem is a statement that can be shown to be true (by a proof)
Also called a Lemma (easy), Proposition (moderate), Corollary (follows easily from something else)

A proof is a valid argument establishing the truth of a theorem
Can use RoI, axioms, and proof techniques

Direct Proof:
$\forall n : P(n) \implies Q(n)$

Assume $P(n)$
$\vdots$ (likely unraveling definition)
$\therefore Q(n)$

Proof by Contraposition:
To prove $P(n) \implies Q(n)$, note that
$P(n) \implies Q(n) \equiv \neg Q(n) \implies \neg P(n)$

Assume $\neg Q(n)$
$\vdots$
$\therefore \neg P(n)$

Vacuous Proof for $p \implies q$:
If $p$ is false, there is nothing to be shown as the statement is always true

Trivial proof for $p \implies q$ is if $q$ is true

Proof by Contradiction:
To prove $p$, note that
$p \equiv \neg p \implies F \equiv \neg p \implies (r \land \neg r)$
"Reductio ad absurdum"

Assume $p$ and $\neg q$
$\vdots$
